title: Paul Routledge: The coalfields charity helping to dig people out of a pit of Tory despair
text:

Decades after Thatcher’s brutal onslaught, our former mining communities have still not recovered.

Unemployment is higher, health is worse, people earn less and the quality of life is lower than in more ­fortunate areas.

No wonder “left behind” towns and villages voted Leave so heavily in the EU referendum. It was a mighty roar of resentment over the way they had been treated.

The Coalfields Regeneration Trust now proposes a five-year strategic plan, involving a £40million investment to create 1,000 private-sector jobs in former pit areas.

Most of the money would come from the Government – peanuts in terms of public spending.

The CRT, a self-funded charity since the Tories withdrew support, has an excellent track record. Over the last 20 years, it has helped create jobs for 30,000 people or got them into work, and upskilled more than a million.

Its programme to build new industrial and commercial property for growing ­businesses is properly costed and would deliver huge social return as well as work.

The coal industry once covered large parts of central Scotland, the North East, ­Yorkshire, Lancashire, Notts, the Midlands, South Wales and reached as far south as Kent – a combined population of 5.7 million. That’s probably a hundred parliamentary constituencies.

In the coming election, every candidate from every party should be asked to sign up for this regeneration programme.

Those who don’t are not fit to represent the people.

By the same token, I hope voters will look beyond the heated passion of Brexit to a party that offers hope, jobs and genuine concern for the issues that affect people’s lives. And it isn’t futile Farage’s, nor the one led by Alexander de Pfeffel Johnson (trading as Boris) who sprays the North with phoney promises of money and power.

His lot got the miners and their ­families into this mess. His claim to get them out of it truly is fake news.

description: With a budget of £40million, 1,000 jobs would be created to inject hope and some prosperity to areas still struggling after Thatcher's cuts
